title: Waraira Repano National Park
description: Waraira Repano National Park is by the coast in northern Venezuela and protects part of the Central Coastal mountains. The tallest mountain there is Pico Naiguatá, which is 2,765 meters (9,072 feet) high.

title: Generalissimo Francisco de Miranda Park
description: Generalissimo Francisco de Miranda Park is a large public park in Caracas, opened in 1961 and designed by Roberto Burle Marx. It’s near Miranda Metro station and run by the government.

title: National Pantheon of Venezuela
description: The National Pantheon of Venezuela is a burial place for the country’s heroes. It was built in the 1870s on the site of an old church from 1744, in the northern part of old Caracas.

title: Birthplace of Simón Bolívar
description: Simón Bolívar’s Birthplace is a very old house in Caracas where he was born. It is a popular place to visit and one of the few old houses still standing in the city.

title: Paseo Los Próceres
description: Paseo Los Próceres is a monument in Caracas near Fort Tiuna and the Military Academy. It has statues of independence heroes, fountains, stairs, and roads. In 1993, it was declared a National Historic Place.

title: Caracas Museum of Contemporary Art
description: The Caracas Museum of Contemporary Art is a modern art museum in the Parque Central area. It opened in 1974 and was started by Sofía Ímber. It was the first museum in Venezuela to have an art library, learning areas, and special programs for children and the blind.

title: Plaza Francia
description: France Square, also called Plaza Altamira, is a public square in Altamira, east Caracas. It opened in 1945 and was first named Plaza Altamira. The name changed after an agreement between Caracas and Paris. It was designed by Luis Roche as part of the Altamira neighborhood project.

title: Poliedro de Caracas
description: The Poliedro de Caracas is an indoor arena next to the La Rinconada racetrack in Caracas. It was designed in 1971 by architect Thomas C. Howard, and its dome was completed in 1974 by Charter Industries and Synergetics, Inc., two US companies.
